page.title: 04Ecology of New Thundersley
page.content: The area has a variety of habitats, but two predominate, namely copse woodland and hedged arable fields. The remainder comprises plotland development and housing estates. {Wildlife }includes badgers, foxes, squirrels, and a wide variety of bird life although some well developed hawthorn copse is being destroyed to accommodate housing. There are two areas of common land still surviving from the Middle Ages:the Great Common and the Little Common. Large oaks dominate the former, with the grass ground cover being controlled by the council gardeners. The area is a dry one averaging 630mm of rain per year and a slightly higher incidence of frost being on a n orth facing slope.
